Topic.Title: Can't wait for the dividend growth

Message.Msg: The dividend will be raised this year. All self respecting semi companies raise their dividend at least once a year. Note: when looking at payout ratios you have to look at cash flow and on earning use the Non-GAAP earnings not GAAP earnings. Note: QCOM, BRCM, MCHP,TXN, and almost on all others analysts report Non-Gaap earnings. For some reason they report GAAP earning estimates only on Nvidia. The difference is 5 or 6 cents per qtr. for Nvidia. Looked at in that context. Nvidia's dividend to earnings payout ratio is extremely low!

It's also been at or around the 200 day MA for the past two weeks now. That bodes well for the move to the upside in the near term imo with any news forthcoming and there does seem to be something planned on Mar 19th after Nvidia's own conference.

Just curious sisula3, why are you posting? You made a big deal about selling out and moving on not that long ago. Really, it's worth your while to keep posting on this board if you weren't interested in buying back in? BTW, shield and GRID are not pie in the sky . . there's plenty of recent news items, just in the last two days, to counter that sentiment.

Ashraf, I suspect you always say you own what you write about. To me your views flip flop on a dime like any good Day Trader's should......It's an honest profession and perhaps you are in that select 10% that make money at it. Been there done that...but it's just too darn hard. Good Luck.
Nah, I don't have the nerves (or time) to be a day trader. I swing trade here and there, but generally make long term bets and stick with them.

Nothing wrong with day trading, swing trading, options, etc. Well maybe options, they suxx in my opinion without access to inside information. You just get suckered by all the call writers. But back to the topic at hand. I did some more reading on ASR agreements and reread the 10K section pertaining to Nvidia's 4Q ASR with an investment bank. From Wikipedia: Accelerated share repurchase (ASR) refers to a method that publicly traded companies may use to buy back shares of its stock from the market. "The ASR method involves the company buying its shares from an investment bank (who in turn borrowed them from their clients), and paying cash to the investment bank while entering into a forward contract. The investment bank will then seek to purchase shares of the company from the market to return to its clients. At the end of the transaction, the company may receive even more shares than it initially received, which are then retired.[1] This method can be contrasted with a typical open market repurchase, where the company simply announces that it is repurchasing shares on the market, and then does so. A firm might choose the ASR method as a way of reducing the number of shares outstanding for a fixed cost, transferring the risk to the investment bank (which is now short the stock) for a negotiated premium. By purchasing the shares in this way, it immediately exchanges a fixed amount of money for shares of its stock. It is currently being theorized that such arrangements are used by management to manipulate earnings figures for incentive compensation and reporting reasons." So Nvidia gave the unnamed investment bank $100M on Nov. 29th or a few days before. Looks like the forward contract was for approx. 60 days. If they are doing the same this quarter, I suspect they started it right after Nvidia went ex div., because they will wan't the settlement date within the quarter. Note: The forward contract period can be as short as 30 days.

I haven't sold everything. And even if I did, I would still follow a stock I'm interested in. Do you find it strange? Btw, pie in the sky is just what you described: Just news items you can't buy anything for. It's not material until you have real revenues.
thank You! really good report!

You actually did STATE that you sold out but no matter, it is 'strange' if you are following something that you think isn't worth investing in anymore and just camp out on a board without any intent to reinvest . . it just implies a real need to vent somewhere that is unhealthy imo, and not realyl constructive. And regarding the news, it's NOT pie in the sky if it's news about actual contracts and commitments regarding the products you claim have no real hope of generating revenue. Those news items are as good as a launch of any product by another OEM . . it's the beginning of another revenue stream. We have had plenty of news items indicating revenue streams have begun regarding Shield and GRID.

Message.Title: The THIRD "shot across the bow".
Message.Msg: I was out most of the afternoon, and was QUITE surprised when I got back and saw the options shorts were able to take the stock back to unchanged, all in the last hour. However, in contrast to the other two spikes to 13, last week, the stock spent a GOOD part of the day at 12.89-90...just look at the chart to the right of this board. And, I was also stunned to see that almost NO March 13 calls traded after I posted around 1:30PM! NONE! So, the OI probably remains at 45-50k calls, and we'll know in the morning. Now, some of you may have seen the SPIKE in BBRY, around 3:20, and the volume went from 35mm shares to 57mm shares in 20 minutes!!! And, the next 20 minutes took it to 82mm shares. The stock jumped 8.15% and then another 2.62% in the after market. It took ONE headline to get this to happen and that IS what's going to happen in NVDA, with all deference to Frank, Mslans, and several others that are ready to give up. It may have to wait until next week...so be it. I'll lose a little on the March 13s that I bought, but my stock position is significant and that's what really matters. That said, I WOULD like to see these options "snakes" get RUN OVER, just once, so that the game of selling calls "with impunity" will finally end. I'm JUST as frustrated as any of you, but please don't give up. Everything is "aligned" for the stock to do what BBRY and others have recently done, and even though those snakes survived another day, they have TWO days to go, and you can bet your last nickel that they were VERY nervous, this morning, given the spike that I was looking for and the surge in volume. They threw over 4mm shares at the stock in the last hour, and walked it back down. Who has the deeper pockets, the Bulls or the Bears? With NVDA likely putting a "floor" under the stock, and John's probably right about another ASR or larger buyback, it depends on what the Big PMs at Fidelity, Paul Tudor Jones and others decide to do. I'm SURE THEIR pockets are deeper . Max

E = Poor Relative Performance Versus Peers and Sector How has the stock done relative to its peers and sector? Year-to-date, the stock is returning 0.31 percent while its competitors, Advanced Micro Devices (NYSE:AMD), Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM), and sector are returning 2.57, 1.38, 3.23, and 6.4 percent respectively. NVIDIA has trailed all of its peers and sector in year-to-date performance. Conclusion NVIDIA engages in an area that is being revolutionized. If the company can allocate its resources adequately, the profits are sure to follow. Currently, the stock is showing now clear indication of trend in its stock price, possibly due to the mixed feelings investors have had about their earnings and revenue growth rates. This in turn has led NVIDIA to be an underperformer, year-to-date, relative to its peers and sector. STAY AWAY from NVIDIA stock for now. STAY AWAY.....FAR AWAY!
What about naked shorts? I agree they can't hold it down forever, but supply and demand doesn't work when there is a bottomless supply. . .

Message.Title: What Is This - More Buyers Than Sellers On Block Trades!
Message.Msg: "NEW YORK (AVAFIN) -- In an effort to determine if stock trades will be profitable, investors often assess block trades data used by both large and small institutions. By the end of the market session, financial institutions exchanged 49 block trades. Further analysis into yesterdays's trading activity reveal that 1,228,131 shares were bought and 521,717 shares were sold, yielding a 2.35 bought/sold ratio. A deeper look into options trading also reveals that traders hedged their positions with options where 3,083 put and 15,025 call contracts exchanged hands leading to a 0.21 put/call ratio. Shares of NVDA closed at $12.74 during the previous session. During the session, the stock hit a low of $12.62 and high of $12.96. The current trading volume of 12M is greater than average volume of 10M shares. NVDA is trading above the 50 day moving average and lower than the 200 day moving average. The stock's 52 week low is $11.15 and 52 week high is $15.49. To date, the stock has gained 3.66% within the last month. " _________________________________________________________________________ Another Share Buy Back is In Progress? I'm fairly certain....hope it's a big one! Two more days left until Jensen's Unprecedented GTC Conference Financial Presentation

Message.Title: Matt Wuebbling summarizes it all: Tegra 4, Tegra Ti win praise from leading semiconductor analyst firm
Message.Msg: ""Our Tegra 4 family of mobile processors has won praise from The Linley Group, one of the industry’s leading semiconductor analysts. Not only did the Tegra 4 compare favorably against Qualcomm’s current offerings, according to analyst Kevin Krewell. It also appears to have an edge over Qualcomm’s forthcoming Snapdragon 800. “Tegra 4 delivers outstanding benchmark results, showing off its considerable capabilities,” Krewell wrote. “These results seem to have caught Qualcomm by surprise.” For The Linley Group’s entire Tegra 4 report, see “Tegra 4 Outperforms Snapdragon” The Tegra 4i also offers impressive performance. “Other integrated quad-core chips will fall far short of Tegra 4i.” analyst Linley Gwennap wrote. “In fact, the new chip is closer to Tegra 4 than to Tegra 3 in performance.” But the 4i’s real edge comes thanks to a tightly-integrated LTE modem placed on the same slice of silicon — or die — as the Tegra 4i’s powerful quad-core processor. “The Tegra 4i die is about half the size of the [Qualcomm] 8974, making it difficult for Qualcomm to compete on price using this die,” Gwennap wrote. “This situation should give Tegra 4i an advantage in mainstream phones.” “By bringing Tegra features and performance to lower price points, the new processor is an attractive alternative to Snapdragon.” SOURCE: NVIDiA website

Message.Title: T4/T4i are Incredible - BUT JUST how good is T5 + Kepler going to be??
Message.Msg: A6 ~ 75 GFlops (pls correct) T4i ~ 80GFlops T4 ~ 96 GFlops Kepler 1 SMX GT 350GFlops at full power in 28nm T5+1SMX GT 200 GFlops! T5+ 2SMX GT 350 GFlops Better Still - T5 + 1SMX in 28nm estimate die size LT 100mm2 and performance is better than Asswell GPU at half the price! Great for Tablets and Chrome books! For Smart phone - will need 20nM to bring the power down. Other GPUs will require twice as much silicon to get that performance.

Message.Title: Linley on Mobile Tegra 4 Outperforms Snapdragon
Message.Msg: Linley on Mobile Tegra 4 Outperforms Snapdragon March 12, 2013 Author: Kevin Krewell Nvidia released benchmark results, performance characteristics, and architecture details of its Tegra 4 application processor at the 2013 Mobile World Congress (MWC). The 1.9GHz Cortex-A15-based device is on track to ship in 2Q13. The company also announced its first smartphone customer, ZTE, which will build a phone using Tegra 4 along with Nvidia’s i500 LTE cellular modem. The unnamed ZTE handset is set to launch in mid-2013 in China. When Nvidia originally announced Tegra 4, it provided little performance data, but it did demonstrate working silicon. At MWC, the company continued its product revelation by disclosing new details of the architecture and its capabilities (as well as limitations). Judging from this preliminary information, Tegra 4 rates as the highest-performing mobile ARM processor—if power constraints don’t throttle the cores. This performance takes aim at Qualcomm’s newest Snapdragon processors; Nvidia offered a wide range of benchmark results that clearly showed Tegra 4 leading both the APQ8064 and (judging from our estimates) the forthcoming Snapdragon 800. Despite Tegra 4’s more powerful Cortex-A15 CPUs and much improved graphics unit, Nvidia claims the chip will increase battery life under normal user workloads compared with Tegra 3. Power efficiency improves through the use of 28nm HPL transistors, which reduce static leakage, and because the more powerful A15 core can process typical workloads at a lower clock frequency and core voltage (reducing active power). On the lab bench, Nvidia’s Cortex-A15 CPU core clearly outperforms Qualcomm’s Krait CPU. Few mobile products, however, have the thermal capacity to run all four Tegra 4 CPUs at their maximum speed, even for short periods. Thus, Tegra 4 systems will not match Nvidia’s quoted performance. But until we see actual products, we don’t know how big the shortfall will be.

Topic.Title: Linley on Mobile Tegra 4 Outperforms Snapdragon

Message.Msg: THIS IS IMPORTANT!!!! "On the lab bench, Nvidia’s Cortex-A15 CPU core clearly outperforms Qualcomm’s Krait CPU. Few mobile products, however, have the thermal capacity to run all four Tegra 4 CPUs at their maximum speed, even for short periods. Thus, Tegra 4 systems will not match Nvidia’s quoted performance."

TOtally agreed. Between growth and income, when you can't have both at their optimum, I would choose growth...that is the reason why most NVDA investors come the stock. I have my other income portfolio: VZ, DUK, NVS - it's better not to mix the investment goals, IMHO.

As usual Ibexx, You and I disagree, but we do have different goals in mind so it should be no surprise. I for one see no reason why growth and income cannot be combined as many of the stellar stocks have performed in the last 3 years. I suspect based on Nvidia's recent actions that they agree with me...i.e. initiating a dividend and starting a share buyback. In no way can anyone imply that this impacts any future growth when cash represents 45% of market capitalization along with $700M in annual cash flow. Initial results of this change has been an increase of institutional ownership to a multi-year high, a reduction in Beta-but still too high, and slight but distinct change in the quality of stock ownership. Too me the recent change by Nvidia to share holder friendly actions is a win-win for the company and those that view Nvidia as an investment rather than a quick hit on some particular weekly options. Certainly the company does not wish their stock to be a plaything of traders. But with all of that said I'm sure you want the stock price to go up as I do so best wishes to you.
